text: Pakistan is expected to compete at the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo. Originally scheduled to take place from 24 July to 9 August 2020, the Games have been postponed to 23 July to 8 August 2021, because of the COVID-19 pandemic. It will be the nation's eighteenth appearance at the Summer Olympics. ==Athletics== Pakistani athletes further achieved the entry standards, either by qualifying time or by world ranking, in the following track and field events (up to a maximum of 3 athletes in each event): ;Track events {|class=wikitable style="font-size:90%" |- !rowspan="2"|Athlete !rowspan="2"|Event !colspan="2"|Heat !colspan="2"|Semifinal !colspan="2"|Final |-style="font-size:95%" !Time !Rank !Time !Rank !Time !Rank |-align=center |align=left|Najma Parveen |align=left|Women's 200 m | | | | | | |} ;Field events {|class=wikitable style="font-size:90%" |- !rowspan="2"|Athlete !rowspan="2"|Event !colspan="2"|Qualification !colspan="2"|Final |- style="font-size:95%" !Distance !Position !Distance !Position |-align=center |align=left|Arshad Nadeem |align=left|Men's javelin throw | | | | |} ==Equestrian== For the first time in history, Pakistan entered one eventing rider into the Olympic equestrian competition, by finishing in the top two, outside the group selection, of the individual FEI Olympic Rankings for Group F (Africa and Middle East). In September 2020, Azad Kashmir, who Khan rode when he qualified, died after suffering a severe heart attack. Athletes and their horse qualify as a pair for the Olympics, leaving Khan's place at the Games in doubt. ===Eventing=== {|class=wikitable style="font-size:90%" |- !rowspan="3"|Athlete !rowspan="3"|Horse !rowspan="3"|Event !colspan="2" rowspan="2"|Dressage !colspan="3" rowspan="2"|Cross-country !colspan="6"|Jumping !colspan="2" rowspan="2"|Total |-style="font-size:95%" !colspan="3"|Qualifier !colspan="3"|Final |-style="font-size:95%" !Penalties !Rank !Penalties !Total !Rank !Penalties !Total !Rank !Penalties !Total !Rank !Penalties !Rank |-align=center |align=left|Usman Khan |align=left| |align=left|Individual | | | | | | | | | | | | | |} ==Shooting== Pakistani shooters achieved quota places for the following events by virtue of their best finishes at the 2018 ISSF World Championships, the 2019 ISSF World Cup series, and Asian Championships, as long as they obtained a minimum qualifying score (MQS) by May 31, 2020. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%" !rowspan="2"|Athlete !rowspan="2"|Event !colspan=2|Qualification !colspan=2|Final |-style="font-size:95%" !Points !Rank !Points !Rank |-align=center |align=left|Muhammad Khalil Akhtar |align=left rowspan=2|Men's 25 m rapid fire pistol | | | | |-align=center |align=left|Ghulam Mustafa Bashir | | | | |-align=center |align=left|Gulfam Joseph |align=left|Men's 10 m air pistol | | | | |} ==References== Category:Nations at the 2020 Summer Olympics 2020 Category:2020 in Pakistani sport
title: Pakistan at the 2020 Summer Olympics
